title: lightsout grades
body: prog lightsout is graded the grades are posted on the course web page click on the grades menu authenticate and you'll see your grades for this homework and a projection for future assessments this is a good way to get a sense of where you are headed in the course and take action if it does not match your expectations the participation entry accounts for all quizzes and labs up to today here are some statistics normalized as percentages max min t avg median stddev you can access test outcomes on autolab note some people got because they ran out of grace days in one case this was an autolab mistake if you believe autolab made a mistake in your case too email me we do occasionally make mistakes if you feel we incorrectly graded a question you have days from now to submit an appeal using the grade appeal procedure on the course web page we will not consider email or oral requests pin

title: ta applications
body: for those of you interested in applying to be a ta the application s can be found at https www ugrad cs cmu edu ta f fall https www ugrad cs cmu edu ta n summer ii note we generally don't hire students as tas the semester after they took we prefer to let the concepts gel for at least a semester said that feel free to apply and we'll see how things pan out pin

title: carnival homework schedule
body: as you are probably aware of carnival starts on thursday april th but thursdays are when programming assignments are typically due in the past when we kept it that way we had a lot of unhappy people working on their code while everybody else was having a good time to avoid this in recent years we have been shifting the schedule a bit namely for about weeks starting right after midterm written and programming assignments will be swapped written hw due on thursdays and programming hw on mondays specifically major changes are in bold written is due on monday april normal schedule nothing is due on thursday april the day of midterm prog is due on monday april written is due on thursday april prog is due on monday april written is due on monday april back to normal schedule prog a is due on thursday april back to normal schedule after that the schedule is normal again see the hw schedule on the course web page for details pin

title: how to do well on programming homeworks
body: as we move into the last part of the semester you'll notice that the programming homework assignments are getting longer more complex and more difficult instead of telling you exactly what to do and how to do it the programming assignment writeups will focus more on describing the fundamental concepts and expectations behind the assignment if you follow these steps you will probably learn more and do better on these assignments start early while in past weeks you might have been able to complete the programming assignments in a couple days you probably will not be able to do this going forward read the writeup carefully don't skip the sections at the beginning and jump to the task descriptions don't rely on folk wisdom from friends and classmates if you haven't read or don't understand every section of the writeup you will have trouble completing the assignment correctly if you have a question or are stuck on a task reread the relevant sections of the writeup first use the search field on piazza admittedly the search functionality on piazza isn't the best but you should be able to get good results by searching for a single keyword don't forget about the beginning of the course remember contracts loop invariants and correctness proofs while you might not be able to completely prove that your code is correct you should be able to reason through your logic and consider whether the code you've written makes logical sense hacking on the code until it works is rarely a good strategy for writing correct code pin

title: office hours

title: a pointer for task
body: i experienced huge confusion about why i failed the big tests but found a useful pointer in the course notes when you add subtract multiply divide compare or do bitwise operations involving multiple variables it s best to make sure that all the numbers you re working with have the same size and same signedness one important gotcha here if you just write the num ber it s treated as an int by default so writing int t i will actually be undefined behavior because is implementation defined to be a bit quantity that can only be shifted by numbers between and inclusive the fix in this situation is to write int t i i i

title: midterm grades
body: midterm is graded the grades are posted on the course web page click on the grades menu authenticate and you'll see your grades for this exam and a projection for future assessments this is a good way to get a sense of where you are headed in the course and take action if it does not match your expectations the participation entry accounts for all quizzes and labs here are some statistics normalized as percentages max min t avg median stddev you may notice that the average and median are some percentage points lower than homeworks this is something we observe every semester and on every exam nothing to worry about but worth keeping in mind as a consequence many people will see a drop in the projections given by the grade forecaster you can access your graded midterms on gradescope there you will find you raw score out of points together with feedback about what each of you did correctly and what you missed we do occasionally make mistakes if you feel we incorrectly graded a question you have days from now to submit an appeal using the grade appeal procedure on the course web page we will not consider email or oral requests

title: written question a
body: while grading question a on the most recent written homework we came across a lot of common missteps that should be acknowledged corrected if you're still confused about these or any other concepts there are office hours in ghc until pm tonight tues as well as the same location from pm wednesday pm o h are replaced by the review session in rashid auditorium casting a struct pointer before accessing a field the arrow operator which accesses the field of a struct pointer has a higher precedence than casting this means that the expression report x current price first tries to get the current price field of x then casts the result to a report this wouldn't compile as you can't dereference a void in c to fix this issue you need parentheses around the cast report x current price note if you're not sure of the order of operations it's better to be explicit and insert extra parentheses than to guess and get it wrong in the future your code may be read by a programmer maybe even your future self who isn't certain of the precedence of the operators so resolving ambiguity is important another common misstep was to add an extra dereference for example report x current price remember that foo bar is equivalent to foo bar so you don't need a star in addition to the arrow unless you are dereferencing a pointer stored in the struct field minheap vs maxheap in this question although we wanted to keep the n largest price increases you needed a priority function that prioritized smaller price increases in the first while loop we want to remove the report from the priority queue that has the smallest price increase pq rem removes the highest priority element first so your priority function needed to assign highest priority to the smallest price increase note remember that 'higher priority' doesn't imply 'higher value' priority is an abstract notion that you the client define by implementing the priority function which you pass by pointer to pq new why does the priority queue's capacity need to be n this was particularly tricky the reason for this was not because of the unused zeroth index in our heap implementation but because of a particular edge case in the given algorithm since the algorithm specifies that you immediately remove a report whenever the priority queue is full at the end of the loop you end up with at most capacity elements in the priority queue in order to keep the n largest elements you needed to have room to store n elements you could think of the loop body as doing the following add one element to the priority queueif there are n elements drop the smallest so only the n largest remain

title: information about midterm
body: some information about the upcoming midterm it is taking place on thursday april th as follows building map students in lecture am sections a aa weh sections b bb dh sections c cc d dd e ee f ff g gg dh students in lecture am sections h hh ph bsections i ii ph csections j jj ph a bsections k kk l ll m mm n nn dh students with accommodations i will email you shortly if you are expecting accommodations and you do not get an email email me immediately at iliano cmu edu everybody must bring his her student id you must arrive on time if you arrive late you will not be given extra time the exam has a duration of minutes the topics are pretty much everything we have covered in class since the beginning of the term to thursday march th included looking at the contents of the practice midterms see course web page written assignments labs and recitations will provide you with a good idea of what to expect we will ask you to write some c c code but we won't be picky about minor issues of syntax we will take points off however for invalid contracts all you can have with you is a single double sided x handwritten cheat sheet the exam will contain nothing that can be just looked up in your notes or in the handouts and we will provide you with all the information you need to solve each question writing a page cheat sheet is an incredibly effective way of reviewing concepts even if you never end up looking at it there will be a review session on wednesday april th from to pm in gh rashid auditorium if you have any doubts that's a good opportunity to get them resolved

title: circularity check
body: in the lecture notes the circularity check is explained as follows this recursive definition can be directly encoded into a very simple data structure invariant is tree it checks very little just that all the data fields are non null as the client interface requires if it terminates it also ensures that there are no cycles a cycle would cause non termination just as it would with is segment the first confusion is the definition is the cycle defined in the directed sense or undirected i assume we are talking about the second case then it is pretty clear that even if our checking function terminates we cannot rule out the possibility that it contains an undirected cycle consider the simple case where we have a triangle rooted at any vertex it is not a valid binary search tree but our function terminates

title: blotched avl rotation example in class
body: earlier in class the example i had in my notes of where a single rotation is not sufficient to restore the height invariant in an avl tree after an insert did not work out here's an actual example consider the avl tree and let's insert t' ok we have a height invariant violation indicated with and what happens if we rotate the tree right at this doesn't work we still have a violation and doing a left rotation on will get us back to the previous tree we need to carry out a double rotation which amounts to first doing a left rotation at in the original tree t' and then a right rotation at let's do it in steps rotate left at note that this is a node below the first violation rotate right at now we are back to a tree that respects the height invariant a valid avl tree when to use each rotation single rotation when the imbalance occurs in an outer subtree i e and the symmetric case double rotation when the imbalance occurs in an inner subtreeand the symmetric case you can see how it all works out with generic tree on the slides posted on the course web site http www cs cmu edu misc avl pdf and done in slightly different way on the lecture notes for the avl lecture if you want to see how insertion works on concrete avl trees there are a number of animations on the web for example http www cs usfca edu galles visualization avltree html if you want to try it out yourself in code see the c implementation available on the course web site

title: written grading bug
body: we discovered a grading issue in task c of written the rubric assumed each chain in the hash table h could contain multiple elements with the same key only the first one of which would be returned by ht lookup but the precondition is ht h prevented that as a result some people got point deducted for not removing all elements with that key in the chain first argument of remove from chain we fixed this by changing the weight of the rubric item removes current element iff key is k from points to pointremoving the incorrect rubric item removes all elements with key k consequently the people above are now getting an additional pt this is already reflected in the grade forecaster sorry for the inconvenience

title: mid semester grades
body: the mid semester grades have been posted on s and will become visible on monday march th at pm s makes it rather cumbersome to release grades ahead of their set schedule for a large class the grades were based on written hw to programming hw to style points for exp included on midterm and on the participation points labs and quizzes up to now that amounted to of the grades that are available in the course all future hw and exams account for the rest the letter grades were computed in a most naive way based on the grade threshold table below g is a g is a etc where g is your cumulative grade on the items above scaled to this number g is also very close to the value the rightmost point of the thick red line in the grade forecaster as you look at your mid semester grade there are a couple of important things to keep in mind of the points for the course are still for grabs this means that if you did not do as well as you hoped for there is plenty of opportunity for corrections the mid semester grade is rather optimistic it does not account for the fact that in general students do much better in homework than in exams and we had many more hw points than exam points so far to get a more accurate sense of how you are doing use the what if section of the grade forecaster and plug your grade for midterm in percentages in for midterm and for the final the updated red line will tell you where you are really headed so some will want to make corrections even if the posted mid semester grade is their ultimate goal the table below is not the way we will compute the course grades this will be based on some kind of thresholds still tbd between letter grades and on your individual performance on the various parts of the course unlike the mid semester grades it won't be based on a rigid formula see course web site for further details also just to dispel any lingering myth this course is not curved see note below for what curving implies and why you really don't want that the table below shows the grade thresholds used to compute the mid semester grades and a count of how many students got each letter grade these numbers are also plotted on the chart

body: prog text buffers or tbuf is graded the grades are posted on the course web page click on the grades menu authenticate and you'll see your grades for this homework and a projection for future assessments this is a good way to get a sense of where you are headed in the course and take action if it does not match your expectations the participation entry accounts for all quizzes and labs up to today here are some statistics normalized as percentages max min t avg median stddev you can access test outcomes on autolab we do occasionally make mistakes if you feel we incorrectly graded a question you have days from now that's the normal days the spring break week to submit an appeal using the grade appeal procedure on the course web page we will not consider email or oral requests notes style regrades for exp are not recorded yet in the grade forecaster there will be another update tomorrow after today's deadline for getting style fixed mid semester grades will be posted tomorrow or monday and will include every piece of assessment up to tbuf included including style fixes for exp

title: how is going now with responses and comments
body: we have put together a brief survey to get a better sense of how things are going from your perspective this will help us correct any issues for the rest of the term and improve future editions the survey is anonymous so please feel free to speak your mind you can find it at https www surveymonkey com r llplnnn the survey will close on next sunday night march disclaimer there are a few things we won't be able to change namely the topics covers and the expectations in terms of homework exams those were set by the people who designed the course survey outcomes first thank to all of those who took the time to fill the survey this input is really valuable for making better in fact without feedback from you we would not be able to know of certain things that need to get fixed below is a summary of responses with some comments in italics what worked well in no particular order programming hw lectures labs office hours recitations piazza bonus tas gradescope instructors written hw given that this is pretty much all we do it looks like everybody found something good in the course although not everybody the same thing what should be done better pretty much the same things that other said worked well minus piazza and gradescope this means everybody found something that can be improved participation points more quizzes lab points points for recitation you shouldn't worry too much a historically the vast majority of the class got the full by the end of the semester b there will be plenty more opportunities to earn participation points c it's a tiny fraction of the total score for the course go over quizzes in class sure why not assess how many students earn the rd lab point and call it a bonus point how many students got points in lab varied a lot throughout the semester from a low of to a high of with an average of while this is fairly normal we monitor the trends and make adjustments to labs to keep it more predictable if that helps you are free to view it as a bonus point written and programming hw are hard compared to what is covered in class of course the lectures are meant to introduce building blocks and basic concepts and do so in the limited time we have available assignments are meant to explore them further by combining them in sophisticated ways lectures and lecture notes are not an exact match the two are very close but indeed there are some differences one the one hand we do want to expose you to different ways to approach the same concept simply because different approaches resonate differently with different students use the one that best helps you learn on the other hand lectures are where we experiment with new ways to present some concepts and if they work we later incorporate them into the lecture notes make more like sorry you graduated from that one already don't force us to go to specific lectures we are college students blame or thank the fire marshal not us by law we are not allowed to fit more people than the official capacity of a room regulating attendance is one way to make sure people don't show up to the lecture labs recitations that are late in the day written programming assignments are unclear while this is not intentional you will see that as you progress through your studies assignments will have less and less precise instructions one reason is that as things get more complex it is harder to spell everything out a second reason is that the parts that are not fully spelled out can generally be inferred from the context or from what you have done so far the most important reason though is that very little is fully spelled out in real life and that's what we are preparing you for in part keep the best autolab submission rather than the last one no objection to that but autolab does not support it and doing so manually would require many more resources than we have available how is the pace of the course too fast a bit fast just right a bit slow too slow any additional comments various expressions of love or dislike for this and that more practice problems there are a few at the end of the notes for each lectures and we will adding more we can also give some at the end of class more bonus problems we are trying to find the right balance weaker students tend to find lots of bonus problems demoralizing while stronger students love them some general comments there are a few things mentioned above that we cannot change as individual instructors these include the topics covered by the course and the performance expectations to pass the class this impacts the kind and difficulty of the assignments and the pace of the course said this the overall group of instructors not just the ones you see review the course periodically and we are taking into account your feedback there are also some things we will not change because based on past experience they lead to reduced learning and lower performance overall these include a few things that some of you find unpalatable like the very notion of a participation grade even if ours is a small one having written and programming assignment as separate hw and the collaboration policy finally there are the logistical challenges of managing one of the largest course on campus was the largest class on campus last fall i haven't heard about this spring yet many of our policies and procedures are dictated by this heavy use of automation strict rules rare exceptions etc we don't have the luxury of being as accommodating as some of the other classes you have taken or are taking simply because we don't have the resources to do so or we would have to significantly lower what you are getting out of this class which we can't do

title: doslingos grades
body: prog doslingos is graded the grades are posted on the course web page click on the grades menu authenticate and you'll see your grades for this homework and a projection for future assessments this is a good way to get a sense of where you are headed in the course and take action if it does not match your expectations the participation entry accounts for all quizzes and labs up to today excluded here are some statistics normalized as percentages max min t avg median stddev you can access test outcomes on autolab we do occasionally make mistakes if you feel we incorrectly graded a question you have days from now to submit an appeal using the grade appeal procedure on the course web page we will not consider email or oral requests in case anybody starts suffering from programming hw withdrawal after the midterm we will be releasing prog one day ahead of schedule on wednesday instead of thursday for everybody else go out and enjoy the good weather

title: written problem c rubric common mistakes
body: please read this before submitting a regrade request for problem c while grading problem c we realized that the rubric items on gradescope did not fully cover all of the possible combinations of code that could arise in responses so we were forced to make certain somewhat hidden changes to how we were grading problem c based on the loop invariants therefore we decided to post a general outline of how we graded this problem point on the gradescope rubric is received either if point was received and the postcondition given was safe or if point was not received and there was an explicit check of safety of array accesses in the postcondition note that this means that if no array access was made in the postcondition and you did not receive point it is impossible to receive points for point point on the gradescope rubric is received either if point was received and the postcondition given was safe or if point was not received and there was an explicit check of safety of array accesses in the postcondition note that this means that if no array access was made in the postcondition and you did not receive point it is impossible to receive points for point the correct loop invariants were anything equivalent to ge seg x a lo and lt seg x a hi n if you had something different this changed how exactly we graded the rest of the problem specifically if the loop invariants were too weak for instance using ge seg x a lo and le seg x a hi n there was a point deduction applied to the problem and no credit could be given for point on the gradescope rubric if the loop invariants were unsafe syntactically incorrect self contradictory or impossible to satisfy no credit was given for points regardless of if they matched the rubric if the loop invariants were something else they were handled on a case by case basis in general though we graded points in context of the loop invariants it was possible for points to be exactly what was written on the rubric but not to receive points due to them not making sense in context of the loop invariants some mistakes to avoid some were common some people used length a instead of n in the postcondition be careful doing this as in many cases this could result in an incorrect postcondition for instance consider the below array where x and n if our postcondition was result length a a result x in that case a result of is the correct answer but would violate the ensures statement a result x a lot of people missed point because of an incorrect negation be careful a b eq a instead a b a b if your code barely fits or doesn't fit in the space provided it likely is overly complicated make your tas happy and increase your chances at getting a point by simplifying your code this goes for your proofs as well test your code a lot of people could have avoided missed points if they just tried it out to see if it worked note this will likely be the only time we will post the full rubric common mistakes for any homework

title: manipulate issues fixed
body: for some of those who carried out optional task autolab was working fine but their manipulated image was not showing properly in the scoreboard this issue is now fixed read on if you want to know more about it the autograder was correctly generating the image as you could see from the bottom of the autolab output that long string of random character is an encoded version of your image but process that places that encoded image on the scoreboard accepts images up to only some maximum size which is documented nowhere all along the output of your manipulate was resized so that it fit in a x pixel square that worked fine except for those who output a square image for those the image was beyond the maximum size and autolab wouldn't display it i changed the setting so that it now fits a x pixel square and that works for almost everybody for person that was still too much and i've since made it a bit smaller

title: stable sorting
body: in lecture we classified sorting algorithms based on whether they were fast or slow and based on whether they were processing the array in place i e they did not need to allocate a new array or not another useful property is whether they are stable stability makes sense when you are sorting not just a number but a record e g your itunes collection or student grades let's take that as an example say i have a spreadsheet with your andrew ids and your homework grades most of the time it is sorted by andrew id that makes entering grades faster but after each hw is graded it is useful to sort it by grade so to see who did well and who needs help when i do that what happens to the andrew ids they can remain in the same order for each grade e g the andrew ids of everybody who got are still in order they end up in shuffled thereby losing the order a sorting algorithm that guarantees is stable entries with the same sorting value remain sorted how do the sorting algorithms we examined fare here's a summary fast in place stable selection sortno yes yes insertion sortno yes yes merge sort yesno yesquick sortmostlyyesno challenge questions what does find min need to guarantee for selection sort to be stable what needs to be guaranteed for merge sort to be stable why is quick sort not stable

title: tips on reasoning about code
body: a common question among students each semester is can i use to justify this statement what kind of statements am i allowed to make this post is an attempt to clarify how we reason about code and structure our proofs in there are two kinds of reasoning that we use in logical reasoning and operational reasoning logical reasoning is using what we know to be true to prove certain properties about code operational reasoning is drawing conclusions about how things change when certain lines of code are run probably the best way to see the difference between these two types of reasoning is with examples when we say things like this we're using logical reasoning we know x from the loop guard y is not modified in the loop on line we know z because we must have entered an if z statement but when we say things like this we're using operational reasoning after an iteration of the loop i' i x is strictly decreasing we know x because x by the loop guard and x x by line it's a common misconception that operational reasoning is always bad and should never be used in fact operational reasoning is often necessary to prove the correctness of functions however operational reasoning is more difficult and prone to error than logical reasoning since you need to consider all of the possible effects any statement could have because of this we want to limit our use of operational reasoning to the smallest chunks of code possible in particular it's very difficult to reason about multiple iterations of a loop at once so you should never make statements like the loop runs y times and x initially so x y when the loop exits in operational reasoning should only be used to prove preservation of loop invariants and loop termination finally to clarify an important point for written an assertion is supported if we can prove it's always true using only logical reasoning

title: transferring files between afs and local machine
body: in order to work on assignments via ssh you'll often need to transfer files between your computer and afs storage for example when you first download a handout or if you are transferring a file to your computer to submit to autolab though this can be achieved with the command scp it is often easier to manage using a gui based ftp frontend for this we recommend filezilla which is available on all common platforms some setup instructions these instructions are based on the windows version so please let me know if your experience differs on mac or linux install the filezilla client note the installer will also ask to install the ad aware browser which you may want to opt out of enter the hostname sftp unix andrew cmu edu as well as your andrewid and password leave 'port' blank click 'quickconnect' under file copy current connection save this connection in the future you can connect by clicking the dropdown 'site manager' menu below the 'file' menu and selecting the connection name on the left side of your screen there is a file browser for your computer and on the right side of your screen there is a file browser for afs storage you can drag and drop files or directories from one side or the other to copy them as a reminder the academic integrity policy requires that you take steps to protect your work against plagiarism your work on afs should be kept exclusively in your private directory anywhere else it is publicly visible if you keep your work on your computer it should be password protected

title: laptop setup office hours
body: if you need help setting up your laptop to work on assignments we will have a laptop setup session on wednesday from to in ghc this is will allow you to work remotely either by installing c on your laptop or by setting up ssh to login to a unix machine note that you can go at any time between and so don't all come at you can also set up your laptop yourself by following the instructions at http c typesafety net tutorial c at cmu html see also piazza postings and a third way is to go to one of the alternate setup labs see and ask a ta to help once you've done the lab to clarify there are two things you need to do this week complete lab the setup lab you must either go to one of the lab classrooms during your scheduled time on friday or go to one of the alternate lab sessions see set up your laptop to connect to the andrew servers this can be done on your own using the instructions on piazza at the laptop setup office hours above or during your setup lab see

title: alternate setup lab
body: the first lab of the semester the setup lab is where you get to practice using unix editing and running c files and submitting to gradescope autolab the writeup and handout are on autolab and also here for your convenience http cs cmu edu misc lab writeup pdfhttp cs cmu edu misc lab handout tgz this lab is exceptionally taking place on friday this week in the cs clusters ghc many of you will want to get that practice sooner than that so that you can feel more confident working on the first written homework therefore we are scheduling additional setup labs wednesday and thursday from to in the cs clusters if you want to take advantage of them just show up notify a ta and go to a free computer you may need to wait since there is a limited number of computers once you're done you can also step aside and work on setting up your laptop see also next post note that you can go at any time between and so don't all come at the same time if you decide to go to one of these additional sessions you don't need to go to the regular lab on friday the setup lab is not graded you don't earn points for it other labs are however see how it works on the web site to clarify there are two things you need to do this week complete lab the setup lab you must either go to one of the lab classrooms during your scheduled time on friday or go to one of the alternate lab sessions above set up your laptop to connect to the andrew servers this can be done on your own using the instructions on piazza at the laptop setup office hours see or during your setup lab above

title: enrollment homework and more
body: if you are reading this you have successfully enrolled in piazza congratulations as said in class we use autolab and gradescope for homework distribution and submission if you were on the roster of this class minutes ago you are now registered on autolab that's where the writeups for all assignments labs and recitations will be posted and where you submit programming assignments you need to self register on gradescope that's where written hw gets submitted to do so go to https gradescope com and sign up using your andrew address no gmail or other email addresses and entry code b these instructions are also part of the setup lab written homework is now posted you can get started it is due next monday at pm in the future we won't use piazza to announce when new hw are posted they come up automatically as per the table on the course web page http cs cmu edu i forgot to mention in class why we have so many assignments written and programming each week most weeks sounds crazy in the distant past they used to be combined as one assignment due each week what happened was that some well many students spent most of their time on the programming part and did what they could on the written part in the minutes before the deadline bad for learning and bad for grades that's why we decided to split them and have different deadlines we observe that the most successful students do them at the same time going back and forth between written and programming and of course they start well ahead of the deadline good luck in and if you have questions come talk to us

title: laptop setup for windows
body: if you have a windows computer follow these steps to set it up to connect to the andrew system if you need help come to one of the setup sessions this week for mac see for linux see download and install mobaxterm home edition installer edition then restart your computer open mobaxterm and click the session button in the top left corner of the window select ssh as the session type enter unix andrew cmu edu as the remote host click the checkbox for specify username and enter your andrew id in the field click ok to connect via ssh and enter your password when prompted you may opt to save your password check to make sure that x forwarding is working properly by running this command eog rjsimmon public couch jpg after a few seconds be patient you should see a window appear with a picture of a couch if that works you're all set up in the future double click the unix andrew cmu edu session in the saved sessions menu whenever you want to connect if you're getting errors or having trouble ask a ta at a setup session

title: laptop setup for linux
body: if you have a linux computer follow these steps to set it up to connect to the andrew system if you need help come to one of the setup sessions this week for mac see for windows see open a terminal window and use the following command to connect via ssh ssh x yourandrewid unix andrew cmu edu check to make sure that x forwarding is working properly by running this command eog rjsimmon public couch jpg after a few seconds be patient you should see a window appear with a picture of a couch if that works you're all set up just use the command from step whenever you want to connect if you're getting errors or having trouble ask a ta at a setup session

title: laptop setup for mac
body: if you have a mac follow these steps to set up your personal computer to connect to the andrew system if you need help come to one of the setup sessions this week for linux see for windows see download and install xquartz then restart your computer open a terminal window and use the following command to connect via ssh ssh y yourandrewid unix andrew cmu edu if that doesn't work try replacing the y with x check to make sure that xquartz is working properly by running this command eog rjsimmon public couch jpg after a few seconds be patient you should see a window appear with a picture of a couch if that works you're all set up just use the command from step whenever you want to connect if you're getting errors or having trouble ask a ta at a setup session

title: how to use piazza effectively
body: as many of you may know piazza is a system for asking and answering questions about lectures assignments logistics exams quizzes and anything else related to the course it's typically an extremely useful tool for getting your ideas answered and questions answered when using piazza and asking questions please keep in mind the following guidelines think before you ask the instructors and tas of the course want to help you help yourself make sure to make your questions detailed enough for us to understand the basics of the problem you're having importantly if you need help debugging a problem with code don't just paste the code in a private post and ask what's wrong also please don't post an autolab result and ask for hints we want you to think about the code you write just like in office hours make sure you have isolated the bug to a few functions or parts of your code or a failing test that you've written from there we'll try to help you get unstuck but you may find that you figure it out just by taking steps to write tests and debug especially if the question is one you should be able to answer on your own tas may wait for some time after a post has been made before they respond there are a couple of reasons for this first we want to encourage students to help one another and this gives time for composing a student response second we want you all to learn the art of talking to the duck see http www codinghorror com blog rubber duck problem solving html and thinking through problems on your own make sure to answer your own question delete your question or change the post from a question to a note if you work it out yourself in order to not waste the course staff's time check for redundant questions before asking the question search for it on the bar on the left someone may have already asked it be active in the course both answering and asking that said do ask and answer questions actively one of the best ways to understand concepts is to teach it to others be sure not to just give the direct answer or write fully coded implementations in your answers in fact we will delete answers like these help your classmates think by giving
